Long-run increase of peak load in Europe under RCP 5-8.5
Long-run increase of peak load in India under RCP 5-8.5
Positive weather anomalies can result in a peak load shock of 20% in both Europe and India under the RCP 8.5; this represents the potential impact avoided by adaptation measures.

Southern European countries experience an exacerbation of summer peaks of up to 20% excluding the additional effect of positive weather anomalies. This represents a potential cost related to increased electricity consumption, although adaptation may reduce it.

Southern European countries experience an exacerbation of summer peaks of up to 33% including the additional effect of positive weather anomalies. This represents a potential cost related to increased electricity consumption, although adaptation may reduce it.
Northern European countries experience reductions in the peak load of up to -20% due to milder winters. This represents potential monetary benefits due to adaptation.

Delhi and Goa are the states with the highest relative increase in daily peak load, reaching values around 33% including the additional effect of positive weather anomalies. This represents a potential cost related to increased electricity consumption, although adaptation may reduce it.

Delhi and Goa are the states with the highest relative increase in daily peak load, reaching values around 30% excluding the additional effect of positive weather anomalies. This represents a potential cost related to increased electricity consumption, although adaptation may reduce it.
Increase in peak demand that needs to be met, representing adaptation costs in terms of required capacity; representing adaptation costs in terms of required capacity.
